awd_titl_txt: Molecular mechanisms integrating fungal growth with plant innate immunity suppression
awd_abstract_narration:
By addressing the fundamental question "How do fungal cells thrive in plant cells?" this project aims to resolve substantial issues in plant pathology regarding what molecular mechanisms integrate fungal metabolism and growth in host cells with sustained plant innate immunity suppression. The project involves forward and reverse genetics, genome-wide proteomic and metabolic approaches, and live-cell imaging to understand how the growth and metabolism of rice blast fungus in host rice cells is facilitated and linked to host immune suppression. This could lead to the development of novel crop protection strategies targeting molecular pathways that are critical for the growth of the fungus but are not required for the normal function of the host cell, and could shed new light on both the basic principles of cell growth, and on the nature and regulation of host-microbe interfaces. The educational objectives will expand scientific education by stimulating undergraduates' science learning, preparing graduate students for scientific life beyond the university, and inspiring scientific interest in underrepresented high school students.

In order to cause plant disease, and in common with other plant-associated microbes, the devastating rice blast fungus Magnaporthe oryzae initially forms intimate associations with living rice cells and grows for the first few days of infection as a symptomless biotroph, elaborating invasive hyphae (IH) wrapped in plant-derived membranes, acquiring nutrients and evading rice innate immune responses as it spreads cell-to-cell. After 3-5 days of infection, M. oryzae undergoes a lifestyle transition to necrotrophy, resulting in disease symptom development, host cell death and sporulation from leaf lesions. How M. oryzae controls the development of IH during the biotrophic growth phase while simultaneously evading or suppressing host innate immunity, and what triggers the transition to necrotrophy following the extended biotrophic growth phase, is almost entirely unknown at the molecular level. This project seeks to address these knowledge gaps by generating and characterizing mutants of M. oryzae that are unable to colonize host plant cells. This is expected to uncover novel cellular, biochemical, and genetic mechanisms governing rice infection. Results from the proposed work could point to novel sources of disease resistance, shed light on fundamental concepts of plant host-microbe interactions, and indicate how beneficial plant-fungal interactions might be promoted while those detrimental to crop health are diminished. The work will foster the molecular training of postdoctoral, graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds through active participation in tackling the real-world problem of rice blast disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Fungi cause devastating plant diseases. The crop killing blast fungus Magnaporthe oryzae (syn. Pyricularia oryzae), which each year destroys enough rice to feed 60 million people, infects host plant leaf cells using a specialized infection structure called an appressorium. Following appressorial penetration, the fungus elaborates invasive hyphae (IH) that grow in intimate contact with living rice cells before the onset of disease symptoms. This biotrophic growth stage is achieved by suppressing the host oxidative burst that otherwise triggers plant cell innate immune responses, and through the deployment of secreted effector proteins. In M. oryzae, apoplastic effectors that accumulate in the compartment between fungal IH and the plant membrane-rich extra invasive hyphal membrane are secreted via the conventional ER-Golgi pathway. In contrast, cytoplasmic effectors destined for the host cell are first secreted into the plant membrane-rich biotrophic interfacial complex (BIC) through an unconventional protein secretion route. Comprehensively understanding how fungi and oomycetes (which use similar infection strategies) deploy effectors, manipulate plant innate immunity and colonize host cells would provide a solid foundation for developing strategies aimed at limiting plant diseases and improving crop health, yet the molecular underpinnings of the infection process are largely unresolved; thus, new and effective mitigation targets are likely obscured. To address this knowledge gap, the goal of this project was to functionally determine the molecular mechanisms governing M. oryzae invasion, biotrophic growth and plant defense suppression in the host rice cell. Using gene deletions, live-cell imaging and multiomic approaches, we characterized M. oryzae mutant strains lacking genes required for pathogenicity while providing an invigorating and rewarding research environment in which underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students could thrive as scientists. In doing so, we enriched our understanding of how the fungus senses and responds to the redox environment of the host rice cell during the early infection stage in order to successfully activate antioxidation strategies that neutralize the rice oxidative burst before accumulated host ROS triggers immunity. We found that the maintenance of endogenous ROS in the fungal ER by spermine was critical to the secretion of appressorial mucilages that ensure host penetration by tightly sealing the fungal appressorium to the host leaf surface. Following host penetration, we discovered that a TCA cycle intermediate, alpha-ketoglutarate, produced in fungal IH from the "self-eating" process called autophagy, is a cell-intrinsic growth signal driving biotrophy by activating a pathway called TOR and also by maintaining the integrity of the biotrophic membranes required for effector deployment. Finally, our work revealed a previously unknown connection between codon usage, codon decoding efficiency and the tuning of effector secretion through the unconventional protein secretion pathway. These latter findings hint at an intragenic codon code specifying cytoplasmic effector secretion that might pave the way to identifying and understanding cytoplasmic effectors in M. oryzae and other pathogens that also utilize unconventional secretion systems to translocate effectors into host cells, such as the notorious plant killer Phytophthora infestans. Together, our breakthroughs have significantly improved our understanding of the molecular determinants of rice blast disease, uncovered fundamental but hitherto unknown processes underlying plant infection that are likely applicable to a wide range of pathogens, and revolutionized our concept of pathogen secretion in host cells through the discovery of a codon-level control system tuning effector deployment - all of which are potential targets for disease mitigation.
